newsitem.title: USA: US poultry exporters can't count on China, Russia.
newsitem.headline: US poultry exporters can't count on China, Russia.

text.p: Political instability in Russia and China means that U.S. poultry exporters of dark meat products need to find new countries to ship their products, a U.S. Department of Agriculture economist told a grain and livestock conference in Chicago.
"I think the industry should be actively seeking new markets for our dark meat products," said Sue Trudell, agricultural economist with USDA.
Russia and China, which includes exports to Hong Kong, account for 68 percent of total U.S. poultry exports, according to USDA statistics.
"Because growth has been concentrated on a few key markets, disruptions can quickly have a major impact," Trudell said.
Poultry exports to Russia were halted last spring when Russian health officials raised concerns about the sanitary condition of U.S. poultry imports.

The issue was resolved and exports resumed, but uncertainty over the health of Russian President Boris Yeltsin and the resulting political shake-up makes "it seem clear that additional disruptions could occur," Trudell said.

Shaken by the Russian situation, industry watchers agree that China's recent announcement to put a ban live and poultry meat imports from the U.S. because of avian influenza concerns could also lead to a disruption in trade.
Poultry products shipped to China include chicken wing tips and chicken claws, two products that have no market in the U.S., Trudell said.
Russia mostly imports U.S. broilers as well as turkey thighs.
